mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
major_drug_interactions: Oral hypoglycemics (increased hypoglycemia risk),Beta-blockers (mask hypoglycemia),ACE inhibitors (increased insulin sensitivity),Corticosteroids (decreased insulin sensitivity)
food_interactions: Inject at same time daily, can be taken with or without food
notes: 24-hour basal insulin. Once-daily dosing. No pronounced peak. Essential for type 1 diabetes.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject at same time daily
notes: 18-24 hour basal insulin. May require twice-daily dosing. Less weight gain than other insulins.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject at same time daily, flexible timing possible
search_keywords: insulin degludec|tresiba|ultra long acting insulin|basal insulin
notes: Ultra-long-acting (>42 hours). Most flexible basal insulin. Lower hypoglycemia risk. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject 0-15 minutes before meals
notes: Rapid-acting analog. Inject just before meals. Peak 1-3 hours. Duration 3-5 hours.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject 0-15 minutes before meals
notes: Rapid-acting analog. Very similar to insulin aspart. Onset 15 minutes.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject 0-15 minutes before meals
notes: Rapid-acting analog. Fastest onset of all rapid analogs. Can inject after meals in some cases.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject 30 minutes before meals
notes: Short-acting human insulin. Inject 30 min before meals. Peak 2-4 hours. Cheaper than analogs.

mechanism_of_action: Lowers blood glucose by facilitating cellular uptake
food_interactions: Inject once or twice daily, roll gently before use (cloudy)
search_keywords: nph insulin|insulatard|humulin n|intermediate acting insulin|isophane insulin
notes: Intermediate-acting. Duration 12-18 hours. Requires mixing (roll bottle). Peak effect 4-8 hours. Cheaper than analogs.

mechanism_of_action: Combination of short and intermediate-acting insulin
food_interactions: Inject twice daily before meals, roll gently (cloudy)
notes: Fixed ratio premix. Less flexible than basal-bolus but simpler. Common in Nigeria for cost and simplicity.

mechanism_of_action: Combination of rapid and intermediate-acting analog
food_interactions: Inject 0-15 minutes before meals, twice daily
notes: Analog premix. Faster onset than human premix. More expensive. Can inject closer to meals.

mechanism_of_action: Decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity
monitoring_type: Renal function, Vitamin B12, Blood glucose
major_contraindications: Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30),Metabolic acidosis,Acute heart failure,Severe liver disease,Hypoxic states
major_drug_interactions: Iodinated contrast media (risk of lactic acidosis - hold before procedure),Alcohol (lactic acidosis risk),Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (metabolic acidosis)
food_interactions: Take with or after meals to reduce GI upset, start low dose and titrate
notes: First-line for type 2 diabetes. GI side effects common initially. Hold before contrast procedures. Vitamin B12 deficiency with long-term use.

mechanism_of_action: Stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells
major_contraindications: Type 1 diabetes,Diabetic ketoacidosis,Severe renal/hepatic impairment,Sulfonamide allergy
food_interactions: Take with breakfast or first main meal
notes: Second-generation sulfonylurea. Risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain. Common in Nigeria due to low cost.

mechanism_of_action: Stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells
food_interactions: Take with breakfast or first main meal
notes: Once-daily sulfonylurea. Lower hypoglycemia risk than glibenclamide. Weight gain common.

mechanism_of_action: Stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells
food_interactions: Take with breakfast
notes: First-generation sulfonylurea. High hypoglycemia risk especially in elderly. Avoid in elderly and renal impairment. Cheap.

mechanism_of_action: Stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells
food_interactions: Take 30 minutes before meals
notes: Second-generation sulfonylurea. Shorter duration than glibenclamide. Take before meals.

mechanism_of_action: Increases insulin sensitivity via PPAR-gamma activation
monitoring_type: Liver function, Fluid retention, Heart failure signs
major_contraindications: Heart failure (NYHA III/IV),Active liver disease,Bladder cancer,Osteoporosis
black_box_warning_text: Increased risk of heart failure, fractures (especially in women), bladder cancer (controversial), fluid retention, weight gain. Not recommended in heart failure.
major_drug_interactions: Insulin (increased heart failure risk),Gemfibrozil (increased pioglitazone levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food
notes: TZD insulin sensitizer. Multiple safety concerns. Fluid retention and weight gain. Fracture risk. Black box for heart failure.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DPP-4 enzyme (increases incretin levels)
major_drug_interactions: Digoxin (slight increase in digoxin levels - monitor)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, dose adjust in renal impairment
notes: DPP-4 inhibitor. Weight neutral. Low hypoglycemia risk. Pancreatitis risk (rare). Renal dosing required. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DPP-4 enzyme (increases incretin levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, twice daily dosing
notes: DPP-4 inhibitor. Twice-daily dosing. Monitor liver function. Pancreatitis risk. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DPP-4 enzyme (increases incretin levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, no renal dose adjustment needed
notes: DPP-4 inhibitor. Advantage: no renal dose adjustment needed. Once daily. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits DPP-4 enzyme (increases incretin levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food
notes: DPP-4 inhibitor. Heart failure hospitalization concern in trials. Renal dosing. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Mimics incretin GLP-1 (increases insulin decreases glucagon)
monitoring_type: Blood glucose, Weight, Pancreatitis signs, Thyroid
major_contraindications: Personal/family history of medullary thyroid cancer,Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia syndrome type 2,Gastroparesis
black_box_warning_text: Risk of thyroid C-cell tumors (animal studies), pancreatitis, gallbladder disease. Contraindicated in personal/family history of medullary thyroid cancer or MEN 2.
major_drug_interactions: Insulin (can combine but monitor),Warfarin (may affect absorption due to delayed gastric emptying)
food_interactions: Inject subcutaneously once daily, start low dose and titrate, refrigerate
notes: GLP-1 agonist injection. Weight loss benefit. GI side effects common (nausea). Expensive. Black box for thyroid tumors (animal data).

mechanism_of_action: Mimics incretin GLP-1
black_box_warning_text: Thyroid C-cell tumor risk (animal studies), pancreatitis, gallbladder disease, diabetic retinopathy complications. Black box warning for thyroid tumors.
food_interactions: Injectable: once weekly SC. Oral: take on empty stomach 30 min before food
notes: GLP-1 agonist. Once-weekly injection or daily oral. Significant weight loss. Very expensive. High demand for weight loss.

mechanism_of_action: Mimics incretin GLP-1
black_box_warning_text: Thyroid C-cell tumor risk, pancreatitis, gallbladder disease. Black box warning for thyroid tumors.
food_interactions: Once weekly subcutaneous injection, refrigerate
notes: GLP-1 agonist. Once-weekly. Pre-filled single-dose pen (easiest to use). Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Mimics incretin GLP-1
monitoring_type: Blood glucose, Weight, Pancreatitis, Renal function
major_contraindications: Personal/family history medullary thyroid cancer,Severe renal impairment,Gastroparesis
black_box_warning_text: Thyroid C-cell tumor risk, pancreatitis, acute kidney injury. Black box for thyroid tumors.
food_interactions: Immediate-release: inject twice daily before meals. Extended-release: once weekly
notes: First GLP-1 agonist. Derived from Gila monster saliva. Twice-daily dosing (immediate-release). Less used now.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits glucose reabsorption in kidney (increases urinary glucose excretion)
monitoring_type: Blood glucose, Renal function, Genital infections, Ketones
major_contraindications: Type 1 diabetes (risk of DKA),Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30),Dialysis
food_interactions: Take in morning with or without food, maintain hydration
notes: SGLT2 inhibitor. Cardiovascular and renal benefits. Weight loss. Genital infections common. DKA risk (rare). Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits glucose reabsorption in kidney
monitoring_type: Blood glucose, Renal function, Genital infections
food_interactions: Take in morning, maintain hydration
notes: SGLT2 inhibitor. Heart failure indication. Genital infections. Fournier's gangrene (very rare). Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Inhibits glucose reabsorption in kidney
monitoring_type: Blood glucose, Renal function, Bone fractures, Amputations
major_contraindications: Type 1 diabetes,Severe renal impairment,History of amputation,High amputation risk
black_box_warning_text: Increased risk of lower limb amputations (primarily toes), bone fractures, DKA. Black box warning for amputation risk.
major_drug_interactions: Diuretics (volume depletion),Digoxin (increased digoxin levels),UGT inducers (reduced canagliflozin levels)
food_interactions: Take before first meal of day
notes: SGLT2 inhibitor. Black box for amputation risk (especially diabetic foot). Fracture risk. Genital infections. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Delays carbohydrate absorption in intestine
major_contraindications: Inflammatory bowel disease,Intestinal obstruction,Chronic intestinal disease,Severe renal impairment,Cirrhosis
major_drug_interactions: Digestive enzymes (reduced acarbose effect),Intestinal adsorbents (reduced effect)
food_interactions: Take with first bite of each meal, increase dose gradually
notes: Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. GI side effects very common (flatulence diarrhea). Limited use due to tolerability. Three times daily with meals.

mechanism_of_action: Stimulates rapid insulin release from pancreatic beta cells
major_drug_interactions: Gemfibrozil (contraindicated - severe hypoglycemia),CYP2C8/3A4 inhibitors (increased repaglinide levels),Beta-blockers (mask hypoglycemia)
food_interactions: Take 0-30 minutes before each meal, skip if skipping meal
notes: Short-acting insulin secretagogue. Take with meals. Hypoglycemia risk. Multiple daily doses. Expensive.

mechanism_of_action: Stimulates rapid insulin release
food_interactions: Take 1-30 minutes before meals
notes: Meglitinide for postprandial glucose. Faster onset and shorter duration than repaglinide. Expensive.
